content: Verizon and AOL require an APP password when using email clients on a PC. I believe you must go to the AOL site and select the security page and can set up the APP password there. See this page for more info: https://help.aol.com/articles/Create-and-manage-app-password
creator: davidsk

content:
According to the documentation you referenced, an APP password is only needed if you have enabled 2 step verification. I have not. My AOL password works on other devices. I think the problem has more to do with the configuration Thunderbird is giving me. Using my desired email address as example@verizon.net , Thunderbird is using the following: Incoming POP3 SSL/TLS 

  pop.verizon.net

Outgoing SMPT SSL/TLS 

  smpt.verizon.net

Username 

  example

I believe when AOL took over the Verizon emails, the POP server became pop.aol.com and the SMPT server became smpt.aol.com Also, I've seen posts that say the username should be example@verizon.net Instead of just example. I've tried all the above combinations and none has worked. Thanks for your help.
creator: wmattiace

content: Try pop.aol.com and smtp.pop.com (I have verizon account - imap - and it uses imap.aol.com and smtp.aol.com. ) Yes, use full email address.

content:
Tried with the following configuration:

Incoming Server 

    Protocol  POP3     Hostname   pop.aol.com     Port  995     Connection Security     SSL/TLS     Authentication Method   Normal Password     Username   example@verizon.net

Outgoing Server 

    Hostname   smpt.aol.com     Port   465     Connection Security    SSL/TLS     Authentication Method   Normal Password     Username   example@verizon.net

Error message: Unable to log into server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password. Thanks.

content: THis thread may help, indicating that OAUTH2 may be your solution: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1360869
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks, David.

Solution was to change the Authentication Method for the Incoming Server to OAUTH2 instead of normal password. TB then went to the AOL site and allowed me to OK TB getting mail from AOL. This was not very intuitive, and I thank you for your help.
creator: wmattiace

content: You're welcome. I'll make a note of this because I know the issue will surface again.
creator: davidsk

content:
Last time I heard of rich text it was a proprietary Microsoft format used by wordpad.

So, I am just a little concerned the article was not entirely accurate or there is an issue in translation. Email in Thunderbird can be either text or HTML, but that has been an option for the last 20 years. Generally email is sent in HTML format and it is probably the most common format for email bodies now. (plain text ruled in the 1990s when Microsoft outlook was plain text only.

Fundamentally you can insert an image into any email you write, either through drag and drop of the image file into the body of the email, paste if the image in one the clipboard (you have copied it) or through the insert image icon on the toolbar.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: try the menu > tools.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: The addressbook is named abook.sqlite. Easiest way to access it is to click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'open profile' and then highlight the file and copy to USB stick. Then, on the other PC, click tools>import>import from a file and then select the sqlite option.
creator: davidsk

content: You might try setting to 'begins with' since your examples fit that format. That doesn't answer your question, but it may prove a useful filter.
creator: davidsk

content:
Oh, so it does in my examples. Sorry that was just me being lazy in typing my question! They don't always have temu at the beginning. The subject might be something like 'Coming soon, yourTemu_pallet' Thank you for the suggestion though.

I guess it hinges on Thunderbird's interpretation of 'contains'. To me that means the subject contains the given string somewhere in its text but it's looking increasingly likely that TB treats 'contains' in a very limited way to actually mean 'this exact whole word is found, with a space either side'. Not all that useful.
creator: hmonline1

content: I just tested your problem and my test worked. I set a filter to pick consecutive letters within a bigger word and was successful. My suggestion is to revisit your filter as it may have an error in it.
creator: davidsk

content:
I've just tried manually running a test filter on something else and it worked, even with different letter case. so you are correct it was the filter that was in error.

I apologise for wasting your time but thank you very much for confirming the filter meaning. I think the issue was that the email I got this morning had the correspondent set to TemuDelivery! but the subject line didn't have temu in it. I saw temu, didn't notice that wasn't in the subject and thought the filter wasn't working!

I'll make another filter to look in the correspondent and body as well. that should do it

Thanks for the help.
creator: hmonline1

content: Finally, I think I understand. If you can access one account from the other, the simplest way to copy the settings in would be to use tools>import>import from another thunderbird installation. If you cannot access it from the seond account, you could copy the profile to a USB stick first, and the simplest way to do that would be to use the import/export utility with its export profile menu.
creator: davidsk

content:
There's a long list of remedies: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1284138

Does the same thing happen in safe/troubleshoot mode (hold Shift when launching TB)?
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thanks for the reply, I found that post earlier and nothing in it helped, I had also tried safe mode with no luck. there were mo addons and I had reset the defaults. I found it odd that it also would not auto complete when typing in any addresses or lists. 

So I UN-installed Thunderbird, renamed the profile folder and reinstalled.  Everything works as it should now.

Thanks for your time!
